title: fanoutqa: What were the release dates of the studio albums released by the band Destiny's Child? (9eb4feb88c3f980b)

chat_history.content: What were the release dates of the studio albums released by the band Destiny's Child?

<document>
<title>Destiny's Child</title>
<fragment>
Three years after the hiatus, members of Destiny's Child reunited to record their fourth and final studio album, *Destiny Fulfilled*.[8] The album introduces the trio to a harder, "urban" sound, and songs featured are conceptually interrelated.[55] *Destiny Fulfilled* saw equality in the trio:[20] each member contributed to writing on the majority songs,[56] as well as becoming executive producers aside from their manager.[57] Released on November 15, 2004, *Destiny Fulfilled* failed to top *Survivor*; the album reached number two the following week, selling 497,000 copies in its first week, compared to 663,000 for the previous album.[58] Certified three-time platinum in the United States,[19] it was still one of the best-selling albums of 2005, selling over eight million copies worldwide;[48] it pushed the group back into the position of the best-selling female group and American group of the year. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
15. **^** "A Book Of Destiny". *www.cbsnews.com*. May 9, 2002. Archived from the original on June 21, 2021. Retrieved February 27, 2021.
16. **^** "It's a Family Affair". *Texas Monthly*. January 20, 2013. Archived from the original on March 25, 2016. Retrieved February 27, 2021.
17. **^** Stacy-Deanne; Kenyatta, Kelly; Lowery, Natasha (2005). *Alicia Keys, Ashanti, Beyoncé, Destiny's Child, Jennifer Lopez & Mya: Divas of the New Millennium*. Amber Books Publishing. ISBN 0-9749779-6-9. Archived from the original on January 8, 2014. Retrieved February 1, 2008.
18. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** "Artist Chart History – Destiny's Child". *Billboard*. Nielsen Business Media, Inc. Archived from the original on November 21, 2021. Retrieved February 24, 2009.
19. ^ ***a*** ***b*** ***c*** ***d*** ***e*** ***f*** "Gold and Platinum". Recording Industry Association of America. Archived from the original on December 19, 2015. Retrieved February 24, 2009.

</fragment>
<fragment>

After the success of their debut album, Destiny's Child re-entered the studio quickly, bringing in a new lineup of producers, including Kevin "She'kspere" Briggs[8] and Rodney Jerkins. Coming up with *The Writing's on the Wall*, they released it on July 27, 1999, and it eventually became their breakthrough album.[20] *The Writing's on the Wall* peaked at number five on the *Billboard* 200 and number two on R&B chart in early 2000.[18] "Bills, Bills, Bills" was released in 1999 as the album's lead single and reached the top spot of the *Billboard* Hot 100, becoming their first US number-one single.[8] *The Writing's on the Wall* has been credited as Destiny's Child's breakthrough album, spurring their career and introducing them to a wider audience.[13][21]




</fragment>
<fragment>
In late 2000, Destiny's Child announced their plan to embark on individual side projects, including releases of solo albums,[28] an idea by their manager.[37] In 2002, Williams released her solo album, *Heart to Yours*, a contemporary gospel collection.[8] The album reached number one on the *Billboard* Top Gospel Albums chart. In the same date *Heart to Yours* hit stores, Destiny's Child released their official autobiography, *Soul Survivors*.[38] Rowland collaborated with hip hop artist Nelly on "Dilemma", which became a worldwide hit and earned Rowland a Grammy;[37] she became the first member of Destiny's Child to have achieved a US number-one single. In the same year, Knowles co-starred with Mike Myers in the box-office hit *Austin Powers in Goldmember*. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

</fragment>
<fragment>
31. **^** Sexton, Paul (April 23, 2001). "Destiny's Child 'Survive' On UK Singles Chart". *Billboard*. Nielsen Business Media, Inc. Archived from the original on September 20, 2014. Retrieved May 22, 2008.
32. **^** "ARIA Charts – Accreditations – 2001 Albums". *Australian Recording Industry Association*. Archived from the original on November 12, 2009. Retrieved May 22, 2008.
33. **^** "Destiny's Child Timeline – Survivor". Sony Music. Archived from the original on November 30, 2015. Retrieved March 22, 2014.
34. **^** VanHorn, Teri (September 24, 2008). "Destiny's Child Put 'Stank' Into Christmas on Holiday Album". *MTV News*. Archived from the original on January 4, 2009. Retrieved May 13, 2008.
35. **^** Reese, Lori (February 22, 2001). "Steel Yourself". *Entertainment Weekly*. Archived from the original on January 5, 2009. Retrieved May 22, 2008.

</fragment>
<fragment>
At the 2001 *Billboard* Music Awards, Destiny's Child won several accolades, including Artist of the Year and Duo/Group of the Year,[25] and again won Artist of the Year among five awards they snagged in 2001.[26] In September 2000, the group took home two at the sixth annual Soul Train Lady of Soul Awards, including R&B/Soul Album of the Year, Group for *The Writing's on the Wall*.[27] Destiny's Child recorded their third album, *Survivor*, from mid-2000 until early 2001. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
Destiny's Child first charted in November 1997 with "No, No, No", the lead single from their self-titled debut album, which was released in the United States on February 17, 1998, featuring productions by Tim & Bob, Rob Fusari, Jermaine Dupri, Wyclef Jean, Dwayne Wiggins and Corey Rooney.[8] *Destiny's Child* peaked at number sixty-seven on the *Billboard* 200 and number fourteen on the *Billboard* Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums.[18] It managed to sell over one million copies in the United States, earning a platinum certification by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).[19] The remix version to "No, No, No", reached number one on the *Billboard* Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks and number three on the *Billboard* Hot 100. Its follow-up single, "With Me Part 1" failed to reproduce the success of "No, No, No". Meanwhile, the group featured on a song from the soundtrack album of the romantic drama *Why Do Fools Fall in Love* and "Get on the Bus" had a limited release in Europe and other markets. 
</fragment>
<fragment>

**Destiny's Child** was an American musical girl group whose final line-up comprised Beyoncé Knowles, Kelly Rowland, and Michelle Williams. The group began their musical career as **Girl's Tyme**, formed in 1990 in Houston, Texas.[1] After years of limited success, the original quartet comprising Knowles, Rowland, LaTavia Roberson, and LeToya Luckett were signed in 1997 to Columbia Records as Destiny's Child. The group was launched into mainstream recognition following the release of the song "No, No, No" and their best-selling second album, *The Writing's on the Wall* (1999), which contained the number-one singles "Bills, Bills, Bills" and "Say My Name". Despite critical and commercial success, the group was plagued by internal conflict and legal turmoil, as Roberson and Luckett attempted to split from the group's manager Mathew Knowles, citing favoritism of Knowles and Rowland.


</fragment>
<fragment>
![](image)The final line-up of Destiny's Child performing during their 2005 Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It concert tour.
To promote the album, Destiny's Child embarked on their worldwide concert tour, Destiny Fulfilled... and Lovin' It Tour. On June 11, 2005, while at the Palau Sant Jordi in Barcelona, Spain, the group announced to the audience of 16,000 people that they planned to officially break up once the tour concluded.[59] Knowles stated that the album's title *Destiny Fulfilled* was not a coincidence and reflected the fact that the breakup was already being planned when the album was being recorded.[60] While making the album, they planned to part ways after their fourteen-year career as a group to facilitate their continued pursuit in individual aspirations. Knowles stated that their destinies were already fulfilled.[60] The group sent a letter to MTV about the decision, saying:




</fragment>
<fragment>
"Bootylicious" and "Survivor" on the television show *Greatest Hits*.[141] Fifth Harmony also incorporated elements of the intro from "Bootylicious" for the intro to their own song "Brave, Honest, Beautiful" (2015).[142]



## Discography[edit]


Main article: Destiny's Child discography

* *Destiny's Child* (1998)
* *The Writing's on the Wall* (1999)
* *Survivor* (2001)
* *8 Days of Christmas* (2001)
* *Destiny Fulfilled* (2004)

**Band members and studio albums**

## Tours[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>

Destiny's Child has sold more than 60 million records as of 2013[update].[3] *Billboard* ranks the group as one of the greatest musical trios of all time,[4] the ninth most successful artist/band of the 2000s,[5] placed the group 68th in its All-Time Hot 100 Artists list in 2008[6] and in December 2016, the magazine ranked them as the 90th most successful dance club artist of all time.[7] The group was nominated for 14 Grammy Awards, winning twice for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals and once for Best R&B Song.




## History[edit]


### 1990–1997: Early beginnings and Girl's Tyme[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
In the wake of the September 11 attacks, Destiny's Child canceled a European tour and performed in a concert benefit for the survivors.[8] In October 2001, the group released a holiday album, *8 Days of Christmas*, which contained updated versions of several Christmas songs.[34] The album managed to reach number thirty-four on the *Billboard* 200.[18] In February 2001, Destiny's Child won two Grammy awards for "Say My Name": Best R&B Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group and Best R&B Song.[35] They also earned an American Music Award for Favorite Soul/R&B Band/Duo.[8] Also in 2001, Destiny's Child sang backup vocals for Solange Knowles, who was the lead, on the theme song to the animated Disney Channel series *The Proud Family*. 
</fragment>
<fragment>
Destiny's Child lent their voices and support as global ambassadors for the 2005 program.[62] *#1's* was also released as a DualDisc, featuring the same track listing, seven videos of selected songs and a trailer of the concert DVD *Live in Atlanta*.[61] The DVD was filmed during the Atlanta visit of the Destiny Fulfilled ... And Lovin' It tour, and was released on March 28, 2006. It has been certified platinum by the RIAA, denoting shipments of over one million units.[19] Notwithstanding the album title, only five of the album's 16 tracks had reached #1 on either the Billboard Hot 100 or the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart; writer Keith Caulfield of *Billboard* magazine suggested that the title was "a marketing angle".[63] Despite this, journalist Chris Harris of MTV said that the album "lives up to its name".[64]



## Disbandment and aftermath[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
26. **^** Vineyard, Jennifer (December 5, 2001). "Destiny's Child, R. Kelly Win Big, Britney Gets Soaked at Billboard Awards". MTV. Archived from the original on January 13, 2009. Retrieved February 26, 2009.
27. **^** Schafer, Gabrielle (September 5, 2000). "Mary J. Blige, Angie Stone, Destiny's Child Win Big at Soul Awards". *Rolling Stone*. Archived from the original on August 18, 2006. Retrieved February 26, 2009.
28. ^ ***a*** ***b*** VanHorn, Teri (December 8, 2008). "Destiny's Child Solo CDs Won't Compete With Group, Each Other". *MTV News*. Archived from the original on January 5, 2009. Retrieved May 13, 2008.
29. **^** "Destiny's Child: Survivors". MTV. Archived from the original on October 15, 2007. Retrieved February 26, 2009.
30. **^** Cohen, Jonathan (May 9, 2001). "Destiny's Child Shoot Straight To No. 1". *Billboard*. Nielsen Business Media, Inc. Archived from the original on February 3, 2019. Retrieved May 22, 2008.

</fragment>
<fragment>
Although band members were affected by the turmoil, the publicity made Destiny's Child's success even bigger and they became a pop culture phenomenon.[10] "Say My Name" topped the *Billboard* Hot 100 for three consecutive weeks, while the fourth single, "Jumpin', Jumpin'", also became a top-ten hit.[21] *The Writing's on the Wall* eventually sold over eight million copies in the United States, gaining eight-time platinum certification by the RIAA.[8][19] The album sold more than 11 million copies worldwide and was one of the top-selling albums of 2000.[23] During this time, Destiny's Child began performing as an opening act at the concerts of pop singers Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera.[8]


</fragment>
</document>
chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Here are the release dates of the studio albums by Destiny's Child:
- *Destiny's Child* (17th February 1998)
- *The Writing's on the Wall* (27th July 1999)
- *Survivor* (2001)
- *8 Days of Christmas* (2001)
- *Destiny Fulfilled* (15th November 2004)

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
